description: The Service Operation intermediate module focuses on the principles, processes, operational activities and functions that enable organizations and individuals to successfully manage how their products and services perform. The SO module focuses on the coordination and execution of activities that enable the ongoing management and operation of the products or services developed or implemented during the service strategy, design and transition phases of the IT Service Lifecycle as well as any technology and support resources that are used to deliver them.
descriptionMD: ** Look for our partner PassionIT Group's information [HERE](https://itprotv-notes-bucket.s3.amazonaws.com/ITIL_OVERVIEW.zip)  Codes for offers are available to members and in the download in the second episode** The Service Operation intermediate module focuses on the principles, processes, operational activities and functions that enable organizations and individuals to successfully manage how their products and services perform. The SO module focuses on the coordination and execution of activities that enable the ongoing management and operation of the products or services developed or implemented during the service strategy, design and transition phases of the IT Service Lifecycle as well as any technology and support resources that are used to deliver them. For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please [contact PassionIT Group](mailto:info@passionitgroup.com).
name: Accredited ITIL Intermediate - Service Operation
subtitle: Service Operation

episodes.description: The Service Operation intermediate module focuses on the principles, processes, operational activities and functions that enable organizations and individuals to successfully manage how their products and services perform. The SO module focuses on the coordination and execution of activities that enable the ongoing management and operation of the products or services developed or implemented during the service strategy, design and transition phases of the IT Service Lifecycle as well as any technology and support resources that are used to deliver them.
episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL Intermediate

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo introduce the ITIL Service Operation lifecycle.  Jo reminds us the key concepts that carries through from ITIL foundations.  In service operation, the goal is to deliver value through the daily business by providing consistent value through carrying out and coordinating services, managing services and optimizes services during regular business.  This sets the stage for the service operations that the series will dive into!
episodes.title: Introduction to Service Operation

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews the key aspects of ITIL foundation by describing the 5 core volume service lifecycles: service strategy, service design, service transition, service operation, and continual service improvement.  She also defines what ITIL means by a Service and Service Management.  Also the key terms that define value: Utility and Warranty by Jo.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundatition Refresher

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the foundation refresher.  Jo reviews asset, resource, capabilities and processes from the ITIL perspective.  She emphasizes the process model and roles associated with processes.  Lastly, she describes the accountability that belongs to the service owner as well.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue in Service Operation Principles.  Jo mentions that the key to the points of continuing to deliver value that is relevant to the business.  She emphasized every part of the IT Service Operations needs to think of balance.  Also in the communication process, we must also maintain relevancy in our communication that is meaningful to the customer as well!
episodes.title: Principles of Service Operation

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with he first  process of service operation: Event Management.  Jo reviews for us the different alerts that help us in Event Management: Informational, Warning, and Exceptions. She reminds us of the activities under consideration when we deal with event management and the different outcomes of  each of these different activities.
episodes.title: Event Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a brief look at distinguishing an incident vs a problem.  Using a very simple illustration, Jo helps to clarify the differences and that one doesn’t turn into the other. (i.e. an incident turns into a problem).  This is meant to be a brief segment to help with the following segments.
episodes.title: Incidents vs Problems

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a look at the incident management process.  Jo emphasizes the goal is two fold: restore normal service operations and deliver value to the organization.  This is done by managing incidents where they minimize the adverse effects, ensure to the agreed SLA and restoration of services in a timely fashion, according to Jo.  This is also a point where it is emphasized to stop and review the concepts up to this point!
episodes.title: Incident Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a look at the incident management process flow.  Jo walks through the process flow to help viewers figure out of what they are facing is an incident or request fulfillment.  She reminds us that once an incident is discovered and logged it is also prioritized based on urgency and impact.  These decisions in the flow process is based on the definitions of incident handling within the SLA.
episodes.title: Incident Management Process Flow

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the incident Management Metrics.  Jo helps us to understand how to achieve the SLA by using metrics like CSF and KPIs to help.
episodes.title: Incident Management Metrics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin with Problem Management Principles.  The emphasis on problem management helps to prevent incidents from occurring, find the root cause of incidents using proactive and reactive techniques that are available to our organization.  It sets the foundations of the some of the details to come in later shows on problem management.
episodes.title: Problem Management Objectives

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss and walk through the problem management process flow chart.  The process flow shows us an effective and efficient way of problem management according to the team. Jo helps us to remember the problems are identified, logged, the problem management team must also categorize and prioritize the problems then take the time to investigate and diagnosis.  She explains also following that, we may need a workaround, resolution or change needed then closure.
episodes.title: Problem Management Process Flow

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue discussing problem management.  This time Jo leads us through the different metrics and relationships that must be considered in problem management.  They discuss the inter-process relationship between configuration, capacity, availability and knowledge management and problem management effectiveness and efficiency.  They also talk about the challenges and risks associated with the problem management process.
episodes.title: Problem Management Metrics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo talk about  equest fulfillment.  Jo leads us through the idea of request fulfillment and identifies that users seek either a service or knowledge in request fulfillment.  Unlike an incident, which causes service interruption, according to Jo, a request fulfillment will provide a consistent and standardized service through the policies that are in place to guide how a company manages this request fulfillment.
episodes.title: Request Fulfillment

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo examine the Request Fulfillment Process Flow. Jo starts from the beginning with understanding the “triggers” and takes us through the closure.  She emphasizes the ideal of the framework as being the important part of the process flow rather than the individual components.  The goal is to make a process flow that meet your organizational needs and provides a better value to you, says Jo.
episodes.title: Request Fulfillment Process Flow

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo complete the request fulfillment process by discussing the inter-process relationships and metrics of request fulfillment process.   The team discusses the some of the considerations when attempting to create CSFs and determining the KPIs to help.  Jo also emphasizes the importance of the configuration management process to provide the single source of reliable and accurate information.
episodes.title: Request Fulfillment Metrics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo introduce the next process Access Management.  Jo describes the principles and shows the process flow for access management.  She relates back the CIA triad principles of Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability.  Also, she describes the metrics use to help us keep our process providing value to the organization.
episodes.title: Access Management Principles and Process Flow

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into Monitoring and Control. According to Jo, this a common service operation activity. Jo discusses monitoring and controls loops: open system and closed system. The purpose is to provide activities that help us to efficiently and effectively meet SLA targets.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Control

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo take a look at several of the Common Service Operation Activities.  Jo provides some insight into some of the activities that are part of the common everyday service operations that make providing service to a company see the value of our services.  The services discussed include:IT Operations, Server and Mainframe Management Support, Network Management, Storage and Archive, Database Administration, Directory Services Management, desktop and mobile device support and middleware management.
episodes.title: Common Service Operation Activities

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with some of the common service operation activities.  This time, Jo take a look across the different processes and shows how integral service operation activities are woven through every process in the ITIL lifecycle.  The following activities are mentioned: Internet/Web Management, Facilities and Datacenter Management, change management, service asset & configuration management, Release and Deployment Management, capacity management, demand management and  availability management.
episodes.title: Common Service Operation Activities Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into some of the remaining activities recommended by ITIL.  Jo mentions the key to keeping good service operations is making sure the communication between teams are effective and efficient as they perform activities that help the service provide value to the business.  She mentions that a great inefficiency that occurs between team is when the communication between them fails when working through a process.  The following processes were also mentioned: knowledge management should result DIKW (data to information to knowledge to wisdom), Financial Management for IT services (capex and opex), IT Service Continuity Management (Proactive) and IT Security Management
episodes.title: Common Service Operation Activities Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the functional area of Service Desk.  Jo emphasizes that the service desk is where the perceived value of the service is determined because it normally is the SPOC, single point of contact to the services.  This, she says, means that it’s important that the people with the right set of qualities should be there.  The service desk personnel must be properly staffed, then properly trained, says Jo.  She also notes that the perception that service desk is a stepping stone means we must be considerate to train and retain individuals to work it properly.
episodes.title: Service Desk

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with additional understanding of the service desk by diving into the performance metrics.  Jo provides a small warning when taking a look at the resulting metrics and looking for direct indicators of performance.  They may not match up, according to Jo.  The team looks at several examples of service desk and discusses the pros and cons of each.
episodes.title: Service Desk Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo briefly discuss the technical management role.  Jo describes this as not being a formalized role necessarily but more of role as needed.  She also helps to define the purpose of technical management within the infrastructure to maintain a stable infrastructure and reviews some of the many activities that go into managing infrastructure too.
episodes.title: Technical Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo dive into operation management.  Jo reminds us that the key goal in all service operation is in delivering value to the business.  This cannot be achieved if the business cannot operate at the “status quo” or if it not responsive to the continual changing business environment, says Jo.  She also reviews the activities to be performed to help achieve effective and efficient operation management.
episodes.title: Operations Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo change topics into application management.  Jo shows us the value of this area is to provide both utility and warranty.  Along with these goals, application support also provides ability to support and address incidents that may arise.
episodes.title: Application Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo review the organization structures.  According to Jo, geography, scale, culture and business environment must be considered when implementing organizational management.  Jo describes these management teams that can be organized along technical specialization, activities, geography; they also have benefits and drawbacks that must be considered too.  She also mentions the possibility of working toward a hybrid approach in which core services can be shared without duplication of services and services that need localization can be provided as needed.
episodes.title: Organizational Structures

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo, take a look at using tools and technology to facilitate all the of the relevant service operation process.  Jo describes the goal is to have all the tools and technology that supports the core functionality so the SLA targets can be met through the process capability.  Obtaining these tools and technology may be based on the MoSCoW (must have, should have, could have and won’t have) prioritization for example, says Jo.  She reminds us that all tools must have relevance to the overall value to the organization.
episodes.title: Technology Considerations

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo discuss the implementation and challenges to service operations. As organizational change is constant, there is a need to implement service operation well, Jo says.  This can be achieved if we do not look at service operation as being another added silo team but as partners in the whole of the IT infrastructure, according to Jo.  She also discusses some of the different challenges and risks that come with implementation.
episodes.title: Implementation and Challenges

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo review some of the different techniques and details when sitting for your ITIL Intermediate exam.  They recommend downloading the sample paper for review.  Jo reviews the details on scoring of the exam.  She also has solid exam advice for delegates preparing for an exam.
episodes.title: Exam Review Introduction

episodes.description: Description: The Service Operation intermediate module focuses on the principles, processes, operational activities and functions that enable organizations and individuals to successfully manage how their products and services perform. The SO module focuses on the coordination and execution of activities that enable the ongoing management and operation of the products or services developed or implemented during the service strategy, design and transition phases of the IT Service Lifecycle as well as any technology and support resources that are used to deliver them.
episodes.title: Exam Review

The SO module focuses on the coordination and execution of activities that enable the ongoing management and operation of the products or services developed or implemented during the service strategy, design and transition phases of the IT Service Lifecycle as well as any technology and support resources that are used to deliver them.
episodes.title: Exam Review Part 2
